text: a key feature in pronunciation is stress
in previous lessons I've talked about
word stress but now I'd like to take the
time to talk about stress in phrases and
in sentences I'm sure you've noticed
that in English we do not stress every
single word equally we don't stress all
the words equally because some words are
more important than others in this
lesson I'd like to help you understand
the difference between content words and
function words you may be asking at this
point why do I need to know about
content words and function words well
because then you'll know which words to
stress when you speak and read aloud in
English knowing which words distress
does not simply make your speech sound
more natural knowing which words to
stress can be the difference between
being understood correctly and not being
understood being misunderstood because
stressing different words can create
different meanings the objectives of our
lesson are to be able to identify
content words and function words so that
you will speak at the sentence level
with correct and natural stress be able
to use stress for emphasis and
understand changes in meaning when
stress is used for emphasis by other
speakers so let's move on now and I'll
explain the difference between content
words and function words
let's talk about the basic difference
between content words and function words
content words carry meaning function
words helped create grammatical
structures content words are nouns such
as Jennifer B Beauty adjectives for
example exciting wonderful verbs such as
grew and in the phrase have grown it's
the main verb grown that's a Content
word adverbs
for example slowly widely
numbers are also content words such as
to hundreds first question words for
example what how why long prepositions
meaning more than one syllable for
example against over demonstrative
meaning this that these those
interjections such as L ouch now let's
look at function words most pronouns are
our function words for example the
personal pronouns such as I you object
pronouns such as me then forms of to be
as the main verb modal verbs such as can
and should exhilarating verbs for
example in the phrase had been wasted
had been are the auxiliary verbs and
they are function words many little
words are function words in English such
as short prepositions one syllable
prepositions on of to for example
possessive adjectives your his there our
etc articles such as the
and conjunctions such as an but so
when we speak in phrases and at the
sentence level will usually stress
content words and not function words a
stressed word is said more loudly longer
and at a higher pitch meaning our voice
goes up when a Content word has more
than one syllable the stress syllable
will be said more loudly longer and at a
higher pitch
exercise 1 listen and repeat
be sure to stress the content words
example I choose to see all that is
interesting and beautiful the content
words are marked in bold in longer words
such as interesting and beautiful I've
underlined the stress syllable and I'll
follow this practice throughout the
lesson let's move on as I read I'm going
to use the mouse to help you sense the
rhythm of each sentence number one
autumn is coming to the caterpillar
answered in a bored tone
three I love to see the shining moon on
a cool autumn night for if you want a
better view climb upward
five the climb had been exhausting
six
the caterpillar found itself being
lifted into the wind
stress within thought groups when words
are grouped into meaningful phrases
there is usually one word that receives
the most stress that word is generally
the final content word example I see the
same world as you but I am able to see
past all that is saddening and
horrifying in this example content words
are still marked in bold but the final
content word in each thought group is
highlighted in purple that content word
in purple is the one that receives the
most stress in that phrase again I see
the same world as you but I am able to
see past all that is saddening and
horrifying stress and fast speech native
English speakers may break the rules of
stress and faster speech this happens
most often when there is a phrase with
the cluster of content words instead of
stressing each content word in that
cluster the speaker may choose to
alternate the stress so that there is a
more natural flow and rhythm examples
the bee grew annoyed in this sentence we
have three content words bee grew
annoyed but I choose not to stress grew
so that I have alternating stress the
resulting rhythm is the bee grew annoyed
dun duh dun one and two
next example autumn brings changes of
astonishing beauty again we have more
content words than words being stressed
the verb brings is not stressed because
I want to create a good rhythm in the
sentence I alternate the stress and what
results is a rhythm like this dum da dun
dun duh dun
one-and-two-and-three-and-four
autumn brings changes of astonishing
beauty
exercise to listen to the sentence as it
is read at a slow rate and again at a
fast rate identify which content words
are stressed in each reading
reading one the ground grows hard and
the wind grows cold
in this slower reading all content words
are stressed they are ground grows hard
wind grows cold reading to the ground
grows hard and the wind grows cold in
this faster reading only for content
words are being stressed ground hard
wind cold the resulting rhythm is 1 & 2
3 & 4 dun duh dun dun duh dun listen
again the ground grows hard and the wind
grows cold
